concept.title: Quick Start Step 5:
concept.shortdesc: The following examples describe a typical process of pushing an application using the Cloud Foundry CLI to a Droplet Execution Agent (DEA) running on .

conbody.note: For more information, see the Cloud Foundry documentation on the Droplet Execution Agent. For detailed instructions on using the cf push command and deploying applications, see the Cloud Foundry documentation on deploying an application.

stentry.p:
The following sample applications will get your started with the cf push workflow:
go-env (Go) A simple Go application to display environment variablesgit clone https://github.com/Stackato-Apps/go-env.git
node-env (Node.js) A simple demo that prints the server's environment variables git clone https://github.com/Stackato-Apps/node-env.git
phpinfo (PHP) Outputs information about PHP's configurationgit clone https://github.com/Stackato-Apps/phpinfo.git
python-env (Python) A simple Python app to show environment variablesgit clone https://github.com/hpcloud/python-env.git
stentry.b: To Prepare for Pushing Your First Application

ol.li: Ensure that you are targeting the desired cluster, for example:cf api http://api.203.0.113.0.xip.ioTo skip SSL validation, add the --skip-ssl-validation option to your command. If you cannot connect to your cluster, ensure that your connection has no proxy settings.

Ensure that you are logged into the desired cluster:cf login
When prompted, enter your username (email) and password.

Set the proxy environment for your applications, for example:cf set-staging-environment-variable-group \{\"http_proxy\":\"http://proxy.example.com:8080\",\"https_proxy\":\"http://proxy.example.com:8080\",\"HTTP_PROXY\":\"http://proxy.example.com:8080\",\"HTTPS_PROXY\":\"http://proxy.example.com:8080\"\}cf set-running-environment-variable-group \{\"http_proxy\":\"http://proxy.example.com:8080\",\"https_proxy\":\"http://proxy.example.com:8080\",\"HTTP_PROXY\":\"http://proxy.example.com:8080\",\"HTTPS_PROXY\":\"http://proxy.example.com:8080\"\}
Create and target an organization:cf create-org <organization> cf target -o <organization>

Create a space, attach it to your organization, and target it:cf create-space <space> -o <organization> cf target -o <organization> -s <space>To save time, you can add all of the commands to a batch file or shell script, for example:cf api http://api.203.0.113.0.xip.io --skip-ssl-validation cf login cf create-org myOrg cf target -o myOrg cf create-space mySpace -o myOrg cf target -o myOrg -s mySpace

stentry.b: To Clone a GitHub Application and Push it to Your Cluster

ol.li: Navigate to the GitHub page of the application and from the Choose a clone URL drop-down list select HTTPS.You can also download the application directly from GitHub by clicking Download ZIP.
Create a directory and clone the application, for example:git clone https://github.com/Apps/myApp.git
Ensure that the yml file in the application directory is configured correctly.
Ensure that you are logged into the cluster:cf login

Push the application:cf push
Your application is deployed to the cluster. At the end of the process, Cloud Foundry displays the URL of the application, formatted using the xip.io wildcard DNS, for example:urls: myAppName.203.0.113.0.xip.ioYou will need this URL to access the application using a web browser. You can also run the cf apps command to see detailed information about your application.If you experience a problem, run the cf delete <appName> command, make the necessary adjustments, and then push the application again. For detailed instructions, see the Cloud Foundry documentation:
Deploying an Application
Deploying with Application Manifests
Troubleshooting Application Deployment and Health
